p.s: In the first quatrain the unknown speaker describes how strict one's love can be.
There we see a pattern about the strong wilwill of nature which he compares with the power of love.
Even powerfullpowerful phenomenomsphenomenons given on our planet such as brass, stone, earth and a boundless sea (v. 1), cannot destroy the power of two humans in love.
But the reality of mortality with this rage (v. 3) will infect their beauty.
He symbolizes it'sits action as a flower, what can be interpreted as lovely, quiet and beautifully graceful.
In versverse 1, we also find an innumarationenumeration, while the speaker lists different word fields.

The second quatrain specifysspecifies on the summer's honey breath (v. 5), what stands for sweetness and the haydayheyday of pure love, that has to hold out against times in life that are not easy and passionate, the wrackful siege of batt'ning days (v. 6) there he points out the contrast between summer honey's breath and batt'ring days to underline the quick reconstruction of human emotions dependent of radical changes, given situations, accomplishments or tests in life.
In verse 7 the speaker uses a methapormetaphor of a rock to explain the hardness of the feeling love which is impreganable (v. 7) but at the same time not so stout (v. 7).
This can be interpretatedinterpreted as the strong relationship in one's love, which seems to be undestroyable but have no sound basis.
Therefore the author uses the climax in v. 8 to underline this point of view.
Because neither gates of steel (v. 8) that are stronger than rocks, can bear the complicated part of love.
Inverse nine he concludes the statement: O fearful meditation, where, alack, which follows three rhetoric questions (v. 10-12).

They ask themselvethemselves if one should forget the good old times of this love which describes as time's best jewel (v. 10) in time's chest, where he uses the personification of time or whoswho's strong hand (v. 11) can bring back these carefree times.
This can implify higher powers such as godGod and the heavenly graces.
He also wishes someone had forbid to spoil the beatuy of love, so that the fair youth had a chance to overthink one's trust in the durabiliy of love: or who his spoil of beauty can forbid (v. 12).
Here we also find aan assonance of the letter o which can also be found in v. 5 O how shall (...), v. 9 O fearful meditation!, v. 11 Or what strong hand (...) and v. 13 O, none (...).
In the last couplet, they compare this feeling as a miracle (v. 13) irrespective of what the speaker mentioned before.
And makes clear, that h is love, in black ink still shines bright (v. 14).
The colour black stands for deep mysterious thoughts and feelings, that can be associated with negativity.
Here Shakespeare placed a typical moral which are included in most of his sonnets.
Even if there are negative aspect in love that may be strining, one's love has to be stronger and harder than them.
Because time best jewel (v. 10) will always be there.
